title: How to Install a Banister

steps.headline: Purchase a banister at a home-improvement store or on the Internet.
Determine the correct height for the banister.
steps.description: Contact your local building department for the codes that govern the installation of banisters. Mark the wall adjacent to the top and bottom stairs with the correct height. Stand a level vertically to ensure the accuracy of your markings. Connect the markings with a chalk line.

steps.headline: Locate the studs in the walls.
steps.description: Do this by using a stud finder. Mark the location of each stud on the wall.

steps.headline: Cut a piece of wood that fits the bottom of the banister.
steps.description: This will be the mounting strip.

steps.headline: Screw the mounting strip onto the wall.
steps.description: Align the screws with the studs.

steps.headline: Apply painter's tape to the areas of the wall that are near the mounting strip.
Stain the mounting strip.
steps.description: The color should match the banister. Be sure to apply 2 coats of stain.

steps.headline: Cut the banister to fit the staircase.
steps.description: Measure the total amount of wood that you will need to fit the staircase. Use a power saw to cut the banister. Miter the ends of the banister. Use a miter box to do so and follow the instructions that apply to the brand that you choose.

steps.headline: Apply the banister to the mounting strip.
steps.description: Mark evenly spaced areas on the painter's tape that you will use to screw it in. These should not coincide with the holes that you drilled for the mounting strip. Screw the banister into place.

steps.headline: Miter a cap for each end of the banister.
steps.description: Use a miter box to do so and follow the instructions that apply to the brand that you choose. Be sure that the caps fit the ends of the handrails properly. Glue them into place. Screw them into place to ensure that they remain sturdy.

steps.headline: Install pre-cut wooden pegs into the holes on the banister.
steps.description: These should have either come with your banister or be available at a hardware or home improvement store. Be sure that they match the color of the banister. Gently use a hammer to secure the pegs into the banister.
